Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Supporting Secure Programming Education in the IDE

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to develop the Application Security IDE (ASIDE) plug-in for Eclipse that warns programmers of potential vulnerabilities in their code and assists them in addressing these vulnerabilities. The tool serves as an always available reminder and educational opportunity during any coding activities. The tool is designed to address input validation vulnerabilities; output encoding; authentication and authorization; and several race condition vulnerabilities.

The goals of this project are: (a) develop and deploy a usable tool that can serve a wide range of students and courses; (b) improve student awareness and understanding of security vulnerabilities in software; (c) increase utilization of secure programming techniques in assignments; and (d) have minimal impact on other course objectives and instructors. ASIDE is used in a range of programming courses, from CS1 to advanced Web programming, at three universities. The project evaluates how students use the tool, the impact on assignments, students' vulnerability awareness, and the impact on the course instructors. The proposed approach investigates whether integrating educational support into an IDE overcomes some of these challenges and provides effective training throughout a student's education.

The ASIDE plug-in can be utilized by a wide variety of students throughout their academic and professional careers. The tool is expected to be adopted by a wide audience and has the potential to improve the security knowledge of students at all levels. The project has a direct impact on students at multiple levels at different institutions, including an HBCU and an undergraduate liberal arts university. The ASIDE plug-in is available for download on the project's website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many of the computer security problems experienced by individuals and organizations are caused by insecure code in the software and websites that they interact with. Our goal is to educate future software developers on the principles and practices of writing secure code. Current computing curriculums often do not include an adequate amount of instruction on how to write secure code. We are examining novel methods for integrating secure coding education across a computing curriculum. We created a prototype tool, ESIDE, to complement current classroom programming courses with secure code instruction. Our tool embodies real-time, contextual learning by providing alerts and explanations to students about potential security problems in the code they are creating. The learning materials can be customized to the knowledge level of the student and the kind of programming course they are taking – from the first programming course for undergraduate students up to advanced courses for graduate students.

 

We evaluated ESIDE in multiple computer programming courses, both for beginner and advanced students. Our results demonstrate that our tool increases students’ awareness and knowledge of secure coding. Students reported that they appreciated learning about the security implications of their code, and how to prevent security problems. Our results also highlight the importance of classroom incentives to using such a tool – students were more motivated to interact and learn with our tool when they were rewarded with even a small amount of assignment credit. Our research demonstrates that students can learn about security concepts while they are writing code with targeted and simple educational materials. ESIDE is available as an open source tool for educators to further develop and customize to broaden secure coding education.
